Dear Mr. Britt:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 1/30/2023.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel Records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the
following information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
One of five new employee records reviewed did not
show proof of education for the employee, identified as
a youth advocate.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the
following information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of five new employee records reviewed showed
the employee's central registry clearance was
c ompleted after the employee's 12/7/2022 date of hire.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following
information and documentation, which shall be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth’s biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
One of eight updated service plans reviewed was three
days late.
Three of eight updated services plans reviewed were
approved late by:

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independence
living services for a youth, the agency shall
document all of the following information in the
case record within 30 calendar days of termination
of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care
and the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Three of three closed youth records reviewed did
not show documentation of (c) and (d) as required
by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that

The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.

note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not

include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers, community representatives,
tribal representatives, for Indian children, or other

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect and
corpal punshiment during this licensing period.
Special Investigation 2022C0420011 was initiated on 2/3/2022. The complaint
alleged a case manager punched a youth in the face as a response to the youth
pushing the case manager; and a full physical altercation occurred. The
investigation revealed the allegations were substantiated; and the action of the case
manager was not reported to children services by the agency. The agency was
cited for the following rules: R400.12206(1) for Staff qualification; R400.12214 for
Compliance with 1975 PA 238; R400.12503(1) for policy and procedures, pertaining
to not following the agency’s no physical discipline and no restraint policy; and
R400.12505(2)(b) for Supervision, related to safety planning. The agency submitted
an acceptable corrective plan indicating: the case manager was terminated; all
current staff and new staff would receive training in Crisis Prevention Intervention by
5/21/2022; going forward incidents of staff/youth altercation would be clearly
documented via an incident report and safety planning related to the youth would be
5

completed by the agency staff. Addtionally, that a meeting was held with all staff on
verbal de-escalation on 1/15/2022; the agency discipline policy is now posted in
clear view for all staff to see related to their requirement to report; the agency would
reach out to the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) related to
scheduling mandated reporting training; and would train all staff on mandated
reporting by 8/1/2022. Lastly the corrective action plan indicated all staff signed a
sign-off sheet of their review of the agency’s policy against physical discipline and
restrant, which would be placed in the employee’s file and the policy would be
posted for all to see. During the onsite visit on 1/25/2023, records were reviewed,
the agency’s posted policy board was briefly reviewed and a screenshot of it was
also provided by the agency. Meetings and training sign-in sheets, staff noncrisis
intervention training certificates were provided/observed; and vertification of the
involved case manager’s termination on 3/10/2022 and manadated reporting
training completion by DHHS-MIC (Maltreatment In Care) was also
observed/verified. With respect to the mandated reporting training, one of the MIC
workers who completed the training for the agency confirmed the training occurred
on 7/6/2022 for 15- 20 agency staff. No other incident like what was alleged in this
incident has been indicated/cited, since the complaint. The agency has completed
this corrective action plan.
AND
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not
related to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective plan related to the agency’s December 2021 Renewal inspection,
where the agency received the following rule violations:
• R400,12509(3)(o) Independent living record.
• R400.12511(1)(c)-(d) Termination.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 722-9 Foster Care Updated Service-Supervisor Approval.
The agency made some progress on its Renewal Inspection corrective action plan,
but it was not totally successful with all areas of the corrective action plan as
indicated by the repeat violations in this Interim Inspection report.
The agency's second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2022C0444022 for a complaint initiated on 9/13/2022. The allegations were that the
agency is not staffing the independent living facility as outlined in their contract; and
the agency withheld all of a youth’s independent living stipend without justification.
No rule violation was cited for the first allegation. With respect to the second
allegation, the agency was found in violation of FOM 722-03 for Independent Living
Stipend. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that indicated
the agency director held a meeting with the program manager on 9/21/2022 related
to the stipend incident/process; and the program manager and all staff were trained
on independent living stipend requirements on that date. Additionally, that the staff
6

involved in the incident was disciplined via a verbal warning; the program manager
and case manager would monitor proof of receipt of stipend by youths monthly
(November, December 2022 & January, 2023) with proof of receipt documented in
the youth’s file. Also, that the director would review the stipend process with staff
during those months. Lastly, that a refresher training on this topic would be
conducted with the staff at the 1/7/2023 staff meeting. On 1/25/2023 during the
agency’s onsite Interim Inspection a review of youth records showed documentation
of various stipend receipt documents. On 1/28/2023, the agency provided proof of
the staff discipline warning (dated 9/19/2022), staff training and director/program
manager meeting (both dated 9/19/2022) and a copy of stipend monitoring review
documents dated 10/28/2022, 11/30/2022, and 12/28/2022. A sign-in sheet for a
1/7/2023 refresher stipend process training was also seen. There has been no new
reported/cited occurrence of this nature since this incident. The agency has
completed this corrective action plan..
The agency's second corrective action plan was related to Special Investigation
2022C0420027 for a complaint initiated 9/20/2022. The allegation was that a youth
went AWOL on 8/24/2022, and the facility failed to notify the youth’s parent.
The agency received a violation for FOM 722-03A for the Absence without Legal
Permission policy. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that
indicated on 12/5/2022, the agency’s director trained the program manager and
case manager on the policy; and future monitoring of such incidents would be
monitored by the program manager; and these such incidents will be reported to
the parent. The agency provided proof of the training with the corrective action
plan. There has been no new reported occurrences of this nature since this
incident. The agency has completed this corrective action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 10/3/2022 was received and reviewed. The
agency assessed its areas of noncompliance as indicated in the December 2021
Renewal Inspection report; and completed all aspects as required by that document.
Interviews
The program manager participated in the 1/25/2023 entrance conference,
preliminary exit that day, and final exit on 1/30/2023. The entrance conference
centered on a review and discussion related to new staff; program/policy changes, if
any since the last inspection; and the record reviews.
The program manager/supervisor, two independent living youth workers, and three
independent youths were interviewed during this inspection.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
This area is not applicable. This agency only provides independent living services.
7

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
